Yaqeen and WISE

In Section (2.4) of his article,[1] Daniel accuses Yaqeen Institute of supporting CVE and counter extremism initiatives by virtue of the fact that Sh. Omar Suleiman participated in a panel hosted by the Women’s Islamic Initiative in Spirituality and Equality (WISE) organization:

Here, Daniel commits the guilt by association fallacy [2] because he neglects to mention the context of Sh. Omar’s contributions to this discussion. In said panel, Sh. Omar serves as the opposing motion to the CVE narrative:

I find that religion is often the disguising language of the essentially political grievances…I do think they’re essentially political grievances, and I think it’s important for people to step up and speak to those political grievances as well, and to not shy away from them. And it’s very difficult when, if the same voice that is being used to speak against extremism is silent on state sanctioned terror or on war or legitimate political grievances, [then] that voice is automatically discredited.

WISE Muslim Women (2017) “WISE Up Summit: Understanding Extremist Recruitment and Early Intervention with Mehdi Hasan,” 8:10 – 9:14 [3]

Those who attended or watched this lecture were also aware that he was the only one to focus on political grievances over ideology:[4]

As such, Daniel needs to rethink his assessment with respect to what he claims others are associated with. If not, then is he willing to concede to supporting the opinions of those he sits on panels with, despite debating against those on the same platform?

SUMMARY:

  • Commits the guilt by association fallacy by accusing Sh. Omar Suleiman of supporting CVE because he took part in a panel with WISE, despite him opposing CVE principles on stage.

Section Errors: 1 / TOTAL: 131

[Back to Top]

Julio Rivera

Also in Section (2.4) of his article,[1] Daniel accuses Yaqeen Institute of being involved in CVE and counter extremism due to hiring a former political analyst for the Department of Defense and research analyst for CPOST, Dr. Julio Rivera, as the Director of Research Operations. However, Daniel is incorrect to make this connection. Although Dr. Julio’s Linkedin profile [2] may cause some alarm for Muslims, there is a great deal of context behind his former career path that should dispel any reservations about his commitment to the Muslim community and his opposition to CVE and the counter-radicalization industry as a whole. Below is a summary of his earlier life and the path to his current position at Yaqeen Institute, told to me by Dr. Julio himself.

Dr. Julio Rivera grew up in an American military family. When he was five years old, he started living in Ankara, Turkey where his mother was stationed. There, he had a positive experience of the Muslim world and grew to love the culture and Islamic ethos. During this time, his mother married a Turkish man and they had two sons together. Young Julio therefore grew up in a household where Islam was respected and religion a core component of his upbringing. While in high school, his interest in religion grew into a desire to become a Catholic priest, so he began visiting seminaries in his local area to see if that’s the life he wanted to live. Needless to say, his interest in a religious life eventually led him down a different path.

September 11th occurred while Julio was in high school, and lead Julio to explore Islam (as many others during the time). He sought to reconcile the positive experiences he had growing up in a Muslim country and the negative media portrayals he was seeing. And although he didn’t accept Islam at this phase, his readings planted the seeds for his conversion. Upon graduating high school, Julio was accepted into Georgetown University where he went to obtain a degree in foreign service. Given that the only life he ever knew was government and military service, this seemed the most logical path to take for his career. And during this time, he met with the Muslim Student Association (MSA). As he started to interact with the Muslim community on campus and continuing his quest, he finally took his shahada. Afterwards, he remained a member of the MSA and continued to learn Islam, including the plights of Muslims everywhere in the world. It was his hope that by entering public foreign service, he could assist his brothers and sisters by bettering their lives – an understandable conclusion for someone raised in a military family.

After graduating from Georgetown, Julio was hired on as a civilian political analyst for the Department of Defense. He was not a soldier nor was he engaged in CVE or counter-radicalization work. Given his background, he was given the task to monitor the political situation in Syria beginning in 2009. His job was limited to reporting political updates and advising government and military officials regarding what they should do to assist civilians in the region. Having become disillusioned with the his government’s lack of concern for the well-being of the Syrian people, he eventually resigned and went back to school to complete pursue his PhD.

During his PhD candidacy, Julio joined the university’s research institute CPOST in 2015 as a University of Chicago graduate student researcher, in hopes that his expertise could be used to better benefit the Muslim community. As such, he was hired specifically to assist Dr. Pape with building upon prior research disassociating religious ideology from suicide bombings and other acts of violence – a narrative that the CVE program opposes.[3] His research findings revealed that foreign occupation and drone strikes were ineffective in combating terrorism, a notion in stark contrast to the War on Terror narrative.

In 2018, Julio resigned from CPOST to complete his PhD and sought a career outside of the security domain, and temporarily shifted into business process/management consulting. In the same year, he moved to Texas to take care of his nephew while his sister was receiving treatment as a result of having been diagnosed with cancer. It was during this phase that he started to see security work as no longer cohering with his desire to help the Muslim ummah.

At this point, he connected with Sh. Omar Suleiman in Dallas as a regular attendee at the Valley Ranch Islamic Center. Upon learning of his expertise in the field of research and his desire to recommit himself to more spiritual benefits, Sh. Omar spoke with Dr. Julio in an effort to explore better ways to utilize his talents related to process and research management, which ultimately resulted in Dr. Julio being hired at Yaqeen.

With that background in mind, it should be asked how Daniel would explain why Yaqeen has never published a single pro-CVE/counter extremism piece before or after Dr. Julio was hired? On the contrary, Yaqeen has published multiple anti-CVE/counter extremism articles after his hire (i.e. Section 5.0 above), including the piece by Dr. Tarek Younis, which Daniel approved of. Ironically, the Yaqeen article by Dr. Nazir Khan (the main article Daniel incorrectly points to as being pro-CVE) was published in November 2016 while Daniel was still working with Yaqeen, years prior to Julio’s appointment in 2019. As such, based on Daniel’s evidentiary standards, doesn’t that article implicate himself more than Julio?

Likewise, how could the research administrator at Yaqeen, Sr. Faduma Warsame, who has been a staunch anti-CVE activist in Minnesota, Dr. Jonathan Brown (the son in law of Dr. Sami Al-Arian) who has written so frequently against counter-radicalization, and research fellow Sh. Muhammad Elshinawy, who was victimized himself by surveillance practices, all work alongside Julio and have no issues with him? Even after all of that, Julio has personally confirmed to me that he is entirely opposed to CVE, counter-extremism and counter-radicalization in theory and practice, like everyone else at Yaqeen.

In summary, Dr. Julio is a revert with a background in government work and counter terrorism research who became disillusioned with the security field and eventually decided to dedicate his talents to more spiritual endeavors. He wasn’t hiding that because he never thought it would be used against him in a vicious smear campaign by a brother who never bothered to clarify his past before spinning together wild Pamela Geller like conspiracy theories. To treat him with disdain because of his past, or accuse him of being some sort of mole, all without seeking any basic verification of who he is just to further a smear campaign against Yaqeen as a whole is incredibly low. Julio is an upright Muslim with outstanding character that every scholar at Yaqeen who has interacted with him would readily testify to. As a revert myself with a past and knowledge of the learning process and experiences we go through to arrive at our place in this ummah, I find it unjust to accuse my brother of engaging in activities that oppress his fellow Muslims. He has since moved on from his role in the security sector and should be afforded the benefit of the doubt that any Muslim should be given, especially considering Yaqeen’s consistent anti-CVE and anti-counter-radicalization stances.

SUMMARY:

  • Falsely accuses Dr. Julio Rivera of working with CVE or supporting CVE based on his former employment, even though he never worked with CVE or supported it even when he was employed with the government and CPOST. Also didn’t bother to inquire with Dr. Julio himself regarding his stance on CVE.

Section Errors: 1 / TOTAL: 132

[Back to Top]

Yaqeen Institute & Aisha’s Age

In this section, I analyze Section (4.3) of Daniel’s article [1] which accounts for 1,650 words or 3.0% of his criticism. After thoroughly deconstructing his arguments, I found 2 major errors which completely undermine his claims and credibility. Here, Daniel targets Yaqeen Institute’s collection More Than Just a Number: Perspectives on the Age of Aisha (RA) [2] claiming its inclusion of one paper is an example of the organization “muddying the water”:

Daniel states that there is “no reason” for Yaqeen to include an eccentric opinion in the collection and that it “undermines” all the other papers. However, this is nonsensical and contrary to the Islamic position for two reasons. The first being that an eccentric opinion may be cited when it constitutes a secondary or tertiary matter which may aid in keeping Muslims from leaving Islam. As the esteemed Sh. Hatem al-Haj notes in paper “In Defense of Faith: Principles and guidelines for Islamic Apologetics”:

It is vital to remember that the goal of apologetics differs from the goal of edicts (fatwá). The apologist is focused on calling people to faith in Allah and helping them embrace the message of Islam. It is far better for a person to believe in Allah and His Messenger ﷺ and follow an eccentric view on some secondary or tertiary matter of the religion than for them to reject Islam altogether. In the area of apologetics, one’s aim is to defend the mainstream positions but simultaneously keep an eye on the people on the fringes and seek to gradually bring them back from the cliff. This would mean that the mention of some eccentric positions may be deemed necessary.

Hatem al-Haj (2020) “In Defense of Faith: Principles and Guidelines for Islamic Apologetics” [3]

For example, although Ibn Taymiyyah held an eccentric view that Hellfire isn’t eternal, we may utilize it in the event that a Muslim is struggling to comprehend or sympathize with the mainstream position (for various intellectual or psychological reasons), all for the sake of keeping them from apostatizing. As such, other views may be mentioned for this reason, as long as they conform to the proper methodology and don’t deny essential tenets of the Islamic faith. With respect to the age of A’isha, Sh. Hatem elucidates further:

Consider the controversy over the age of ʿĀʾishah رضي الله عنها at the time of her marriage to the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ. We have a text in Ṣaḥīḥ al-Bukhārī where ʿĀʾishah herself states that she was 9 years old when she consummated the marriage with the Prophet. Most apologists defending this position cite extensive historical evidence concerning the cultural norm of early marriage in pre-modern society, the fact that ʿĀʾishah was actually engaged to Jubayr ibn Muṭʿim before marrying the Prophet ﷺ, the data concerning early physical maturation prior to the industrial revolution, other physiological and psychological data, and so on. Naturally, these justifications require some time and effort, as well as educational background on the part of one’s audience to comprehend. Some apologists instead have relied on extrapolations and inferences from other evidence (including other hadith as well as biographical sīrah works) to build a case for an older age at the time of marriage, saying she was 18 years old. Is this an invalid (bāṭil) position or an eccentric (shādhdh) one that may be still mentioned in the course of our apologetics? Here, methodology is critical; how you arrived at your conclusion is more important than simply looking at the conclusion itself while disregarding methodology. If someone rejects the hadith in Bukhārī because they do not believe that the hadith of the Prophet ﷺ or the Sunnah have a role to play in Islam, their opinion will be considered void and invalid (bāṭil), since their approach does not align with orthodox methodology and accepting such a viewpoint entails nullifying the scriptural sources upon which Islamic teachings are built. On the other hand, however, if a scholar argues that the collective weight of inferences from other reports raises the possibility of a subtle flaw (ʿillah) or discrepancy (shudhūdh) in the particular report mentioning the age of 9, their argument may be speculative and deemed less probable but it does not rely on methods foreign to Islam.


While there are some who have advocated this view, like the contemporary Hadith scholar Ṣalāḥ al-Dīn al-Idlibī and others, this position, while being alluded to by some imams, has not been explicitly upheld by any of them in Islamic history. How one interprets the various hadith on this topic does not impact one’s theology nor does it have a real impact on Islamic law (since any rulings derived from this hadith are also established by other evidences in Islam). So it’s important to ask what is truly at stake here. While the view that ʿĀʾishah is 18 years old may be an eccentric view, the speculative inferences from other reports in combination with the historical evidence drawn upon makes it a possibility that could still be mentioned to leave a crack open and not shut the door completely in the face of an audience that will be unable to comprehend the justification of the mainstream position. If we take the route of mentioning the eccentric position to facilitate an easy answer to a problem many find otherwise intractable, we must also ensure that the majority of energy in one’s apologetics is focused on justifying the mainstream position.

Hatem al-Haj (2020) “In Defense of Faith: Principles and Guidelines for Islamic Apologetics” [4]

Thus, this is one of the reasons why the opinion was included in the collection. So for Daniel to state there is “no reason” to mention it is a little naive and removed from what is permissible to reference in the Islamic tradition. That said, there is also a second reason for including the opinion which appeals more to those who follow the mainstream position. In this regard, Sh. Hatem notes that the inclusion of such a view is necessary for comprehensiveness and to ultimately showcase its flaws when compared to the mainstream position:

Eccentric positions are not all of equal weight. Some may be closer to invalid positions than minority positions, while others may be plausible interpretations. It is important that the mention of those positions for the sake of debate is done in a way that will guard against their promotion as viable alternatives to the mainstream ones. As well, it is important to note that in an academic discussion of a subject, the mere mention of an extremely shādhdh or even bāṭil position, for the sake of comprehensiveness and thoroughness in one’s treatment of the subject, does not constitute endorsing or promoting such positions. This is well known in Islamic scholarship. In fact, scholars in almost every Islamic discipline frequently enumerate long lists of opinions on a particular matter, some of which are so far-fetched that they do not even warrant a rebuttal. Indeed, when dialoguing with audiences that are familiar with heterodox views, it may compromise the credibility and persuasiveness of one’s approach to omit such positions and thereby appear less familiar with the breadth of views expressed on the subject.

Hatem al-Haj (2020) “In Defense of Faith: Principles and Guidelines for Islamic Apologetics” [5]

In other words, the inclusion of invalid or eccentric opinions does not necessarily equate to the endorsement of said opinions. In fact, to the contrary, an opinion mentioned alongside its own refutation and a comprehensive defense of the mainstream position cannot possibly be seen as approval. In this regard, Yaqeen included an essay by Faraz Malik titled “The Age of Aisha (ra): Rejecting Historical Revisionism and Modernist Presumptions”[6] directly refuting the arguments made in the paper Daniel has a problem with:

So if Yaqeen were truly “muddying the water,” why would it include a refutation of the eccentric view absent a rebuttal? If the organization were truly seeking to confuse the masses by making all positions equal, why even include an uncontested refutation to begin with?

Imagine if Yaqeen published Daniels “review” on its website without a response. How would this be perceived? Would this act by Yaqeen been seen as “muddying the water” or as a concession of defeat? Rightly, it would be perceived as a concession and that Daniel were correct in his criticisms. Yet, when Yaqeen includes an uncontested refutation of an eccentric view, Daniel regards this as “undermining”.

Clearly Yaqeen is promoting the mainstream position here. Although it mentions an eccentric opinion, it primarily acts as a means to bolster the mainstream view, while holding a secondary function as a potential means of saving those dangerously close to leaving Islam. This is not “muddying the water,” but being as comprehensive as possible towards meeting the needs of the Muslim community. Thus, Daniel commits a non-sequitur fallacy with his criticism. His insistence that Yaqeen not mention any eccentric opinions at all is not only contrary to the Islamic tradition, but is anti-intellectual and unbecoming of a self-proclaimed “skeptic” who seeks to inform and educate others.

SUMMARY:

  • Claims there is “no reason” to include eccentric opinions in Islamic works/collections despite there being two very good reasons for doing so: to save Muslims who are doubting their faith and to be comprehensive in understanding the subject (so to bolster the mainstream position).
  • Commits a non-sequitur fallacy by accusing Yaqeen Institute of “muddying the water” for presenting an eccentric view, despite publishing its uncontested refutation alongside it.

Section Errors: 2 / TOTAL: 134

[Back to Top]

Yaqeen Institute & Evolution

In this section, I analyze Sections (6.0-6.1) of Daniel’s article [1] which accounts for 1,600 words or 3.0% of his criticism. Therein, he focuses most of his attention on Dr. David Jalajel’s piece, “Tawaqquf and Acceptance of Human Evolution.”,[2] which was released as a guest submission as part of a larger collection of perspectives on evolution that all affirm that all human beings are the descendants of Adam and Eve (who were real, not allegorical). After thoroughly deconstructing his arguments, I found 19 major errors which completely undermine his claims and credibility.

He begins by summarizing the orthodox Islamic position on the concept of human common ancestry in evolutionary theory:

Daniel concludes his summary with the following:

Daniel commits the fallacy of suppressed evidence [3] when he claims “nowhere does Yaqeen convey that accepting the evolution of human beings from another species is Islamically unacceptable”. This is patently false. For instance, Dr. Khan and Sh. Yasir Qadhi dedicate an entire section to defending the orthodox Islamic position in their piece, “Human Origins: Theological Conclusions and Empirical Limitations”:

In the opening passage of Surah al-Nisa, God describes all humanity as descendants of Adam and Eve: “O Humankind, be mindful of your Lord, Who created you from a single person, and made from him his mate, and from the both of them He created many men and women” (Qur’an 4:1). The verse is patently explicit: all of mankind, without exception, originates from one couple.


The evidences from the Qur’an and Sunnah on humanity being descended from these two parents are too numerous to recount in the span of this article. Suffice to say that the entirety of the Muslim ummah in every generation since the beginning of Islam has understood that humankind is descended from Adam and Eve, who were created directly by God. [….]


Clearly, in light of such an explicit and vivid narrative, claims that human beings have descended from other species besides Adam are not theologically tenable. Some may attempt to confine the meanings of the texts as tightly as possible and discard any textual inferences (dalalat al-nass) in an effort to squeeze in human evolution from creatures alongside Adam. However, as the subsequent discussion shall illustrate, a sound approach would entail according both scriptural theology and philosophy of science their appropriate epistemic weight, using both scriptural and scientific knowledge to arrive at a deeper understanding. The discourse on reconciling reason and revelation is not new but rather the subject of voluminous writings in Islamic history. Essentially, three different approaches have arisen in Muslim history corresponding to three famous historical figures: Ibn Sina (d. 428 H), Abu Hamid Al-Ghazali (d. 505 H), and Ibn Taymiyyah (d. 728 H).[….]


How do these three approaches pertain to the topic of evolution? In the case of the story of human origins, we have such an explicit narrative, one that is deeply rooted in countless passages throughout the entire Qur’an and numerous Prophetic statements, that there is no choice other than to accept that this is what Allah intended for us to believe. The sheer quantity and diversity of nouns, adjectives, and verbs used simply make any linguistic re-interpretation (or taʾwīl) implausible. Meanwhile, attempts to describe the entire account as symbolic or allegorical (takhyīl) may be tempting for some contemporary Muslim scientists, but it leads to logically incoherent theological ramifications and contradicts the Qur’an’s own emphasis that these accounts are literally true narratives (3:62). Developing an epistemologically sound foundation upon which both scriptural and scientific truths work in concert is a far more fruitful endeavor.

Nazir Khan and Yasir Qadhi (2018) “Human Origins: Theological Conclusions and Empirical Limitations” [4]

Likewise, Dr. Jalajel states the following in his paper, “Tawaqquf and Acceptance of Human Evolution”:

It is safe to say that the idea that Adam and Eve were directly created and were ancestors for all human beings living on the Earth in later times is something that has never been called into question by pre-modern Sunni scholarship, and that this assumption accords with the apparent meaning of the texts of the Qur’an and Sunnah. This, then, can be regarded as the classical, orthodox Sunni position on the matter. The rest of the paper will take this to be the case and will not challenge it.

David Jalajel (2018) “Tawaqquf and Acceptance of Human Evolution” [5]

So, not only does Daniel misrepresent the Yaqeen articles on this subject, but the very paper he chooses to focus his criticism on already undermines everything he claims is problematic with the institute’s approach.

Daniel Commits Tahreef of Dr. Jalajel’s Statements

Daniel partially quotes a paragraph from Dr. Jalajel’s paper and accuses him of believing that Adam and Eve are “mythical”. But this is a clear case of the fallacy of quoting out of context,[6] because Dr. Jalajel is simply describing the beliefs of those he disagrees with. To showcase this, the reader should be reminded of the paragraph that comes prior to the one Daniel references, where Dr. Jalajel explicitly declares his acceptance of the orthodox position:[7]

From this point, the reader should be skeptical of Daniel’s accusation, because it is not logically possible for Dr. Jalajel to believe both the orthodox view that Adam and Eve are real and that they’re “mythical” simultaneously. So why then was the word brought up to begin with? We need only examine the full paragraph Daniel quotes from:

The reader will immediately notice that Dr. Jalajel brings up the word “mythical” to describe what “scientifically-minded critics” would argue. He then examines the meaning of the word, its negative connotations, and ultimately attempts to use the term as a tool to undermine the argument of said critics through an if/then (i.e. conditional) statement. He states clearly “If it could be argued that Adam and Eve are ‘mythical’…then by the same logic, it is impossible for science to critique the special creation of Adam and Eve”. But not only does Daniel leave out all the preceding context leading up to this sentence, he completely modifies the statement itself to make it appear as though Dr. Jalajel believes Adam and Eve are “mythical”. The reader should notice that Daniel only quotes the highlighted portion of the text, removing “If” and the dependent clause after the comma. He then capitalizes “it” and replaces the comma with a period, transforming an obvious conditional statement into a declarative one. This is nothing short of pure deception.

For those who may still not quite understand the problem here, let’s substitute Dr. Jalajels comments with the Qur’an, and then apply Daniel’s methodology. Utilizing the slides below, imagine someone quotes ayah 43:81, but removes the preceding context, the word “if”, and the dependent clause. Subsequently, they capitalize the second word and replace the comma with a period. The result? They conclude the Qur’an teaches “Allah had a son.” (Astaghfir’Allah). Would any sincere Muslim see this as and honest an legitimate means of criticism? No they would not.

Making Excuses for Dishonesty

It should be clear to the reader at this point that Daniel committed tahreef. He literally changed the words of Dr. Jalajels statement in his paper. This is obvious and indisputable. Not too long after Daniel published his “review,” a brother by the name of Rameez Abid found the above error and wrote about it in a Facebook post:[8]

Daniel subsequently responded to the above post in his follow up article, “Yaqeen Institute Promotes Evolution of Humanity from Apes”:[9]

Rather than admit his error, Daniel doubles down and attempts to justify his deceptive alterating of the statement. And how does he do this? By arguing that Dr. Jalajel “describe[s] Adam and Even as mythical throughout the paper” and that it’s “central to his whole argument”. But this is a red herring fallacy, or “a digression that leads the reasoner off the track of considering only relevant information,”[10] because it is not a proper defense against the accusation that he deliberately misrepresented that quote. Daniel literally modified a sentence, removing key words and a whole clause, to make it appear that Dr. Jalajel believed the very thing he was using to undermine his critics. And now, in addition to this, Daniel has the audacity to commit a straw man fallacy [11] by further misrepresenting the paper. How so? Daniel states that Dr. Jalajel claims that Adam and Eve are “mythical throughout his paper,” but the only place where the words “myth” or “mythical” are mentioned is in the very paragraph shown above where he is attempting to refute those who claim this. And secondly, at no point was this one paragraph “central” to the argument of his 9,000+ word essay.

Daniel goes on to to evade further:[12]

Daniel claims he “never accused” Dr. Jalajel of saying Adam and Eve were allegorical. But this is patently false, because he clearly does accuse him of this in his initial argument:

If Daniel never accused Dr. Jalajel of saying that Adam is “allegorical,” then why claim he and Yaqeen are “trying to introduce these same concepts to describe Adam”? The only “concepts” mentioned in this paragraph are “mythical” and “allegorical stories,” which some Christians and Jews adopt with respect to their own scriptures. Anyone with rudimentary English comprehension and basic reasoning skills can see the obvious deception here. A such, Daniel has committed the fallacy of hedging, which is when “you refine your claim simply to avoid counter evidence and then act as if your revised claim is the same as the original.”[13]

Perhaps more importantly, however, if Daniel truly “never accused” Dr. Jalajel of believing Adam and Eve were “myths” in the pejorative sense, why even bring this up as a problem to begin with? If Daniel truly knows that Dr. Jalajel holds the orthodox position with respect to Adam and Eve (i.e. that they existed, were miraculously created, and are the parents of all mankind), then why accuse him of deviancy?

Finally, Daniel recognizes that Dr. Jalajel himself responded in an article defending himself against these accusations.[14] Despite his passionate defense, however, Dr. Jalajel eventually felt forced to edit the document due to the confusion spread by Daniel and his followers. Daniel then proceeds to claim victory, completely oblivious (or apathetic) to the fact that had it not been for his flagrant dishonesty and the subsequent fitna caused by it, Dr. Jalajel wouldn’t have felt the need to clarify to begin with:[15]

What’s ironic about Daniel’s reasoning here is that he appears completely unaware of his own hypocrisy. If Yaqeen editing the paper vindicates him, then doesn’t his editing of Dr. Jalajel’s statements vindicate Yaqeen? Why distort his statements to begin with if the paper was clear enough to merit the accusations? Daniel’s conclusion is so absurd it undermines everything he’s argued for up until this point. As such, no amount of pitiable sophistry is going to save him from his slanderous error. “What a joke,” indeed.

But Daniel is already aware of his sophistry, because he consistently quotemines that one paragraph to make it appear as though each statement is scattered in various places of the article, having no immediate connection or context to the other. For example:

As the reader should recall, the quote Daniel is using here is the statement which comes immediately after the conditional sentence qua refutation of Dr. Jalajel’s critics. Yet, Daniel misframes it as though this is a point where the author is attempting to convince Muslims to accept human evolution, because he seemingly believes “Adam and Eve are myths”. As such, this is yet another fallacy of quoting out of context. That said, Daniel’s subsequent analysis of this quote is far more problematic.

Adam and Eve: Empirically Verifiable?

Daniel claims Dr. Jalajel’s is wrong to classify Adam and Eve as part of the ‘Unseen’. However, he is severely mistaken in doing so, openly contradicting the Qur’an’s explicit references to the beginning of creation and stories of Prophets being regarded as the ‘unseen’. This is apparent in numerous passages:

I did not make them witness to the creation of the heavens and the earth or to the creation of themselves, and I would not have taken the misguiders as assistants.

Al-Qur’an, 18:51

It was said, “O Noah, disembark in security from Us and blessings upon you and upon nations [descending] from those with you. But other nations [of them] We will grant enjoyment; then there will touch them from Us a painful punishment.” That is from the news of the unseen which We reveal to you, [O Muhammad]. You knew it not, neither you nor your people, before this. So be patient; indeed, the [best] outcome is for the righteous.

Al-Qur’an, 11:48-49

And he raised his parents upon the throne, and they bowed to him in prostration. And he said, “O my father, this is the explanation of my vision of before. My Lord has made it reality. And He was certainly good to me when He took me out of prison and brought you [here] from bedouin life after Satan had induced [estrangement] between me and my brothers. Indeed, my Lord is Subtle in what He wills. Indeed, it is He who is the Knowing, the Wise. My Lord, You have given me [something] of sovereignty and taught me of the interpretation of dreams. Creator of the heavens and earth, You are my protector in this world and in the Hereafter. Cause me to die a Muslim and join me with the righteous.” That is from the news of the unseen which We reveal, [O Muhammad], to you. And you were not with them when they put together their plan while they conspired.

Al-Qur’an, 12:100-102

That is from the news of the unseen which We reveal to you, [O Muhammad]. And you were not with them when they cast their pens as to which of them should be responsible for Mary. Nor were you with them when they disputed.

Al-Qur’an, 3:44

Anyone with rudimentary knowledge of orthodox Sunni creed knows that all of the matters mentioned above are regarded as “unseen”:

Of the matters of the unseen in the past: information about the creation of the heavens and the earth and Adam, and the story of Iblis, and then after that the stories of the Prophets who came before, and the previous nations.

Encyclopedia of Sunni Theology (2020) “News of the Unseen” [16]

Does Daniel believe that the Qur’an and Sunnah aren’t enough to confirm the existence of Adam and Eve? That we need the approval of “modern academics” who require “hard empirical evidence” to believe in the existence of our first father and mother? He appears to suggest as much in his response to Rameez:[17]

Here, Daniels reliance on his secular education appears to be taking precedence over the Qur’an and Sunnah. Ironically, by contesting clear evidence from Allah and the Islamic tradition, he reveals the lingering influence of an Atheistic Liberal paradigm for the necessity of empirical qua scientific verifiability. Does Daniel wish to continue disputing with the Qur’an and Sunnah regarding the status of Adam and Eve? Does he wish to dispute Allah and His Messenger (ﷺ)? Astaghfir’Allah.

Finally, his erroneous conclusion appears to come from a very basic error in logic known as a the fallacy of hypostatization, which is “inappropriately treating an abstract term as if it were a concrete one” and is a type of category mistake.[18] Daniel’s confusing the term’s ontic usage with its epistemic one. In other words, although it is true that Adam and Eve aren’t like angels or jinn (i.e.categories of entities formally referred to as ‘Unseen’) they are empirically unverifiable by those who came after them (i.e. cannot be known by the senses).

A Lesson in Logic

Daniel attempts to explain the supposed logical implications behind Dr. Jalajel’s statements by providing three premises. He then asserts that the only conclusion one can come to is that Dr. Jalajel believes all of humanity are descended from both Adam and Eve and some “ape-like creatures in the distant evolutionary past”. However, this is a straw man fallacy. How so? Dr. Jalajel’s subsequent paragraph explains an example of how this would be possible:

If God created all the creatures by way of evolution and then decided to honor one individual member of one species by creating it ex nihilo, then there is no reason to assume that He would be obliged to furnish that individual with physical or genetic markers to set it and its descendants apart from their fellow creatures. A distinction enjoyed by Adam was the honor he had in God’s regard, but this was not necessarily due to some physical or mental characteristic, and even if it were, we have no way of pinpointing with any level of certainty what that characteristic might be. The distinctions that can be found in the hadith, as we have seen, are all honors that God bestowed on Adam, and not inherent physical or mental qualities. Therefore, the idea that Adam was directly created does not make his descendants any less a part of the broader biological human family that they are genetically a part of, any more than Jesus being born of a virgin makes him any less human—biologically or otherwise. Admittedly, Jesus’s miraculous birth has a direct consequence on his historical lineage—he is not attributed to the family of any man but rather called “the son of Mary”—but his membership in the broader human family is not in the least way compromised. [….]


Science, for its part, can only speak about the empirical evidence it finds, which indicates that Homo sapiens evolved from other hominid species. If an individual specimen of one species were created by God ex nihilo, this would leave no empirical trace for scientists to identify. For believers, it would be a miracle, grounded in scripture, and by definition, beyond the laws of nature—something which science cannot address and has no interest in exploring.

David Jalajel (2018) “Tawaqquf and Acceptance of Human Evolution” [19]

In other words, it’s very much possible that Allah could have simply created the Hominid species and then made Adam a separate creation with similar biological characteristics. So all human beings today are from Adam, but not from the other Hominid species. Thus, while scientists may classify Homo sapiens with specific genetic markers, this doesn’t necessitate that the Adamic variant evolved from a common ancestor. This is not at all difficult to comprehend and is quite within the realm of logical possibility. However, Daniel attempts to address this possibility with yet more fallacious reasoning:

Daniel states that Dr. Jalajel “confirms” his interpretation, which is clearly false. He then goes on to commit yet another straw man fallacy by insisting Dr. Jalajel believes the reader may potentially not be from the line of Adam, but “descended from pre-hominid apes”. But as was shown earlier, Dr. Jalajel already conceded that every human being on earth today is a descendant of Adam. Again, for emphasis:

So no, this is not “undiluted deviance,” but Daniel refusing to accept the fact that Allah can do as He pleases and that the Adamic creation can share properties with other living beings without necessarily being related to them. Do we not have hearts like other animals do? Lungs to breathe oxygen? Brains to think and manage our organs? Digestive systems to consume food and water? Did not Allah make Adam from the substance of the Earth itself (i.e. dirt)? Does Daniel believe mankind is only special because we have different genetics? If Daniel concedes the possibility of this scenario, then he concedes the debate and undermines his entire argument.

Evolving Integrity Any Time Soon?

Daniel commits yet another straw man fallacy by suggesting Dr. Jalajel accuses every Muslim in history of “not understanding the Quranic account of Adam’s creation,” because they all “understood the creation of Adam as a biological origin of humanity”. But this is patently false. Dr. Jalajel only accuses contemporary Muslims of reading too much into the Qur’an on account of being faced “with the question of human biological origins” related to the preceding discussion on the nature of evolutionary theory and common ancestry, not biological origins per se. The nature of this question is made clear in the paper:

The same distinction between theological and scientific considerations applies to the belief that the people on Earth today are descended from Adam. This is, as we have determined, the position of classical Islamic theology. Anyone who believes this cannot doubt that Adam’s descendants have diversified in color, stature, and physical appearance as they spread throughout the Earth. In the absence of any unequivocal textual evidence describing Adam’s earliest descendants in detail, there would be no way to gauge the extent or rate of genetic and phenotypic change that has taken place among Adam’s later progeny. Therefore, scriptural evidence cannot be used by theologians to indicate whether Adam’s earliest descendants would have been classified biologically as Homo sapiens or possibly as some earlier human species. This means that theologians would not attempt answers to questions like whether Homo neanderthalis were from Adam’s descendants, any more than they could argue whether or not creatures that scientists would classify as being biologically Homo sapiens had already evolved on Earth and were populating it before Adam’s arrival upon it. All the evidence for hominid evolution, up to and including the evolution of Homo sapiens in a direct line of descent, is empirical, and there is nothing in Islamic scriptures that confirms or contradicts the existence of those hominids. Consequently, it is not a matter of religious belief to accept or reject the scientific account of hominid evolution up to and including organisms which are taxonomically Homo sapiens. It remains purely a scientific question. From a scriptural standpoint, it is not possible to determine precisely when Adam and Eve made their appearance on Earth nor whether they may have met any pre-existing hominid species.

David Jalajel (2018) “Tawaqquf and Acceptance of Human Evolution” [20]

Daniel continues building his straw man:

A shown prior, not only was Dr. Jalajel discussing contemporary biological theories, but believing the evolutionary account of Hominid origins is not mutually exclusive to believing in the existence of a distinct and unrelated Adamic variant.

Daniel goes on to write:

Here, Daniel makes four egregious errors. First, he essentially accuses Dr. Jalajel of lacking expertise in his own field, when in fact he was a lecturer in Islamic Theology and Legal Theory in Darl-Uloom Cape Town, South Africa,[21] unlike Daniel whose credentials only qualify him to lecture on Youtube and have thus far proven he’s incapable of comprehending basic Islamic creed (e.g. “Adam and Eve are not ‘Unseen'”):

Second, he commits the fallacy of equivocation [22] by framing the word “possible” as meaning ‘permissible’, whereas Dr. Jalajel is using it to mean ‘conceivable’. Third, he complains that Dr. Jalajel shouldn’t refer to said possibility as “some Muslims,” because their views are heterodox. However, Daniel yet again showcases his ignorance of orthodox Sunni creed. Just because someone holds a heterodox belief (even one of kufr) this does not automatically make them a kafir, because they may simply have a misinterpretation that requires clarification prior to judgment of their status as Muslims.[23] And finally, Daniel commits yet another fallacy of quoting out of context, because he isolates this statement from Dr. Jalajel’s other possibilities and ultimate conclusion that said position is heterodox:

As such, this should be sufficient for any serious student of knowledge to understand what is expected of someone to be and remain Muslim.

Finally, Daniel concludes his criticisms with the following:

Daniel accuses Dr. Jalajel of wanting to accept some “status quo,” attempting to negatively read into his intentions and motivations. But this is a type of ad hominem fallacy known as the vested interest fallacy, which is “when a person argues that someone’s claim is incorrect or their recommended action is not worthy of being followed because the person is motivated by their interest in gaining something by it, with the implication that were it not for this vested interest then the person wouldn’t make the claim or recommend the action.”[24]

In conclusion, Daniel’s assessment of Yaqeen Institute’s views on evolution is marred by dishonest portrayals of the entire collection and, more specifically, Dr. Jalajel. Even after being called out for his deceptive tactics, he chose to double down, refusing to admit to any fault through additional misrepresentation. Even Dr. Jalajel was humble enough to edit his paper despite the false accusation, but Daniel could not even be bothered to entertain the possibility of being wrong. Furthermore, he commits to a number of inconsistencies when discussing the Islamic tradition’s position on Adam and Eve, unwittingly contradicting the Qur’an and Sunnah with his ignorant claims. As such, Daniel should engage less in critically evaluating his peers and more in critically evaluating his own understanding and unethical behavior.

SUMMARY:

  • Commit the fallacy of suppressed evidence by claiming “nowhere does Yaqeen convey that accepting the evolution of human beings from another species is Islamically unacceptable,” despite evidence to the contrary
  • Commits the fallacy of quoting out of context by altering Dr. Jalajel’s statements, thereby ascribing to him the belief that Adam and Eve are “mythical,” despite the fact that he was simply using his critics own argument against them.
  • In response to criticism against his deceptive tactics, he doubles down with a red herring fallacy by arguing it was justified for him to alter the quote because Dr. Jalajel “describe[s] Adam and Eve as mythical throughout the paper” and that it’s “central to his whole argument”.
  • Likewise commits a straw man fallacy by mischaracterizing the nature of Dr. Jalajel’s argument, because the word “mythical” was only used in one paragraph when discussing the evaluation of critics.
  • Commits the fallacy of hedging by denying he ever accused Dr. Jalajel of claiming/believing Adam and Eve were “allegorical,” contrary to the obvious.
  • Undermines his own argument by suggesting Dr. Jalajel’s editing of his paper to clarify vindicates the accuser, without realizing his own edits of the latter’s statements vindicate Dr. Jalajel and Yaqeen Institute.
  • Commits another fallacy of quoting out of context by rendering Dr. Jalajel’s statements about “Biologist are not concerned with mythical beings…” as a means to persuade Muslims to accept evolutionary theory, when in fact it was a continuation of his refutation of his critics.
  • Erroneously claims that Adam and Eve are not of the Unseen and Dr. Jalajel is mistaken, despite Quranic evidence to the contrary, unwittingly disparaging Allah and His Messenger.
  • Ironically holds to Atheistic-Liberal sentiments necessitating empirical qua scientific verifiability.
  • Commits the fallacy of hypostatization by confusing the ontic meaning of the word ‘unseen’ with its epistemic meaning.
  • Commits another straw man fallacy by suggesting the only logical implication behind Dr. Jalajel’s views is that the Adamic creation shares descendants with “ape-like creatures,” despite evidence to the contrary.
  • Commits another straw man fallacy by insisting Dr. Jalajel believes the reader could possibly be of non-Adamic descent, despite evidence to the contrary.
  • Unwittingly limits the Power and Wisdom of Allah by mocking the possibility that Adamic creation could possess similar traits to hominids without being related.
  • Commits another straw man fallacy by suggesting suggesting Dr. Jalajel accuses every Muslim in history of “not understanding the Quranic account of Adam’s creation,” because they all “understood the creation of Adam as a biological origin of humanity,” despite evidence to the contrary.
  • Wrongfully accuses Dr. Jalajel of lacking qualification in aqida when he posses the credentials to teach Islamic Theology and Legal Theory in Darl-Uloom Cape Town, South Africa.
  • Doesn’t realize his own lack of credentials and how that affects his understanding of aqida (e.g. “Adam and Eve are not ‘Unseen'”).
  • Complains that Dr. Jalajel doesn’t make takfir, yet doesn’t comprehend there is no established justification for doing so (yet) according to orthodox creed.
  • Likewise commits another fallacy of quoting out of context, despite Dr. Jalajel concluding that it is heterodox to deny the special creation of Adam.
  • Commits the fallacy of vested interest by ascribing negative intentions and motivations to Dr. Jalajel.

Section Errors: 19 / TOTAL: 153

[Back to Top]

Daniel’s Windmill

“Fortune is directing our affairs even better than we could have wished: for you can see over there, good friend Sancho Panza, a place where stand thirty or more monstrous giants with whom I intend to fight a battle and whose lives I intend to take; and with the booty we shall begin to prosper. For this is a just war, and it is a great service to God to wipe such a wicked breed from the face of the earth.” [….]


“Look you here,” Sancho retorted, “those over there aren’t giants. they’re windmills, and what look to you like arms are sails – when the wind turns them they make the milestone go round.”


“It is perfectly clear,” replied Don Quixote, “that you are but a raw novice in this matter of adventures. They are giants; and if you are frightened, you can take yourself away and say your prayers while I engage them in fierce and arduous combat.”

Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra (2018) The Ingenious Hidalgo Don Quixote de la Mancha, Trans. John Rutherford, pp. 63-64.

For over a decade I have dedicated myself to the defense of Allah, His Messenger (ﷺ), and the ummah against the vulgar and hateful propaganda of Islamophobes. As a result, I learned a great deal about their mentality and tactics over the years, meticulously deconstructing their erroneous claims through the use of my education in philosophy, which Allah blessed me to have. This is the reason why I joined Yaqeen Institute, utilizing it as a platform to continue dismantling doubts and strengthening the iman of my brothers and sisters. As such, I never thought the day would come where I would have to focus my attention on the beliefs and actions of a fellow Muslim.

As I mulled over Daniel Haqiqatjou’s “review” of Yaqeen Institute, I not only felt betrayed, but utterly disappointed with what was presented to me. Here I saw a graduate of Harvard and Tufts University completely violating the academic codes of conduct he swore to uphold in acceptance of his credentials. I still cannot fathom how someone of his aptitude would resort to such fallacious reasoning and dishonest representations of his intellectual opposition. More egregious still, I could not believe my brother in faith would resort to the very same tactics employed by our enemies – tactics so obvious that, having memorized the various polemics of Robert Spencer, David Wood, Ayaan Hirsi Ali, Pamela Geller, etc. over the years, there were times during my writing of this missive where I literally had to remind myself I was responding to a Muslim.

I cannot say with certainty that Daniel Haqiqatjou is some “disgruntled ex-employee” of Yaqeen Institute, nor do I care any longer if that’s the case. But what I can say with certainty is that his desire to combat the reactionary hegemony of Secular Liberalism has led him to become a reactionary himself, totally devoid of any semblance of integrity or honor. His obsession with the institute and its seeming “liberal tendencies” strikes me as in the very least misguided, if not bordering on pathologically delusional. Not only is there no evidence for his abrasive accusations of many of its fellows, but he has systematically undermined himself and his agenda in almost every conceivable way through the publication of his duplicitous “review”. As Allah states in the Qur’an:

Do not mix truth with falsehood or hide the truth knowingly.

Al-Qur’an, 2:42

Although I must concede, without any hesitation, that Yaqeen Institute for Islamic Research is by no means perfect or without error. It is young and it is growing. It’s fellows and staff are human and therefore fallible. I have seen them make mistakes, err in judgments, and at times express themselves in anger, fear, and even tears. But at no point have I ever met any of them who exhibited a lack of integrity or honor in their sworn dedication to Islam and the Muslim ummah. While we may never agree on everything, I can safely say I am the worst among them, for they inspire me to be a better Muslim every day. As such, their reputations are far more valuable to me than my own. Unlike Daniel, who proudly declares he “sleeps like a baby” because he has no regrets, the members of Yaqeen Institute I’ve come to know and love over the years have always struck me as individuals who take their deen seriously, encouraging one another to fear Allah, willing to accept criticism for their flaws and correct them accordingly. They do this because they abide by the Sunnah of our Prophet (ﷺ):

Aisha narrated: “There was no behavior more hated to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) than lying. A man would lie in narrating something in the presence of the Prophet (ﷺ), and he would not be content until he knew that he had repented.”

Jami` at-Tirmidhi, 1973

What can be said of Daniel Haqiqatjou, who spends his time unjustly destroying the reputations of his spiritual family members? Would the scholars of old have accepted his behavior? Would they have accepted knowledge from him? Or would they have warned against him? In the narration of hadith, integrity was paramount the validity of a source. As Abu Bakr Kahtib al-Baghdadi states:

One who lies about something besides the hadith of the Messenger of Allah (s), his narrations are rejected. We have previously mentioned the opinion of (Imam) Malik ibn Anas in that regard. His hadith must be accepted if his repentance is (publicly) confirmed…Abdullah ibn Mubarak said: Among the punishments of a habitual liar is that he is rejected even when he is honest.

Abu Bakr Aḥmad ibn ʻAli Khatib al-Baghdadi (1970) Al-Kifayah fi ’Ilm al-Riwayah, p. 117.

And of course, narrating hadith is not exactly the same as what you claim of other Muslims, but is it not a proper analogy with regard to those we should take knowledge from? Is the honor of a Muslim not sacred? Are not the heirs of the Prophet (ﷺ) due respect? Do we truly wish to say that dishonesty against each other is acceptable as long as it doesn’t pertain to hadith? Where is the gheerah for the Prophet (ﷺ) and his Sunnah if we deny his hatred for such a vice?

But even if the reader doesn’t find this good enough reason to reject Daniel Haqiqatjou’s teachings, they must accept the overwhelming evidence presented in this missive. In other words, if a lowly student of knowledge like myself can completely eviscerate the arguments of him and his twelve member team of “Muslim Skeptics,” what does that say about the quality of their scholarship and the value of their opinions?

Advising the Ummah

O you who have believed, if there comes to you a disobedient one with information, investigate, lest you harm a people out of ignorance and become, over what you have done, regretful.

Al-Qur’an, 49:6

Asalaamualaykum wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh,

First I wish to thank you all for taking the time to sincerely read over this missive and grasp its contents. Many these days are apathetic towards properly comprehending a text, and you should be commended for your efforts. That said, I do not wish to take up too much more of your time. I only ask that if you believe the contents of this document that you defend its integrity. Many may attempt to destroy my reputation in response, thinking that by dishonoring me they can undermine everything I’ve stated herein. You may even witness these smear tactics. As such, I only ask that you do not concern yourself with my reputation, but the reputation of my peers – that you defend the integrity of this document for their sake, not my own. I give my reputation to them freely for for the sake of the truth, and I only desire that this missive not be belittled by such tactics.

Some of you reading this may be my students or friends. You know me very well and you know that I hold to my integrity more than anything else. You have witnessed me refute the enemies of Allah in the past with utmost precision and honesty, and you have even witnessed me apologize to those enemies when I have done them wrong. For all the flaws that I may possess, you know that lying is not one of them. So please, trust this document, even if you can no longer see much good in me because of those who try to poison the well.

As for those who support Daniel and have contributed to his dishonest tactics and propaganda, I ask you to reconsider your loyalties and repent to Allah for the shameful judgements you’ve made against my peers, based not on honest mistakes, but your own willful ignorance. The mere fact that I had to write this missive is a damning testament to that, because none of this would have needed explaining if most of you just took the time and effort to read beyond a meme or a few sentences from one of his articles. I say this with disappointment, but also with hope that you will do the right thing and cocede. May Allah guide you.

As for every single of you, my brothers and sisters, you have an obligation to stand against injustice, especially when one Muslim oppresses another. As the Qur’an declares:

And if two groups of believers fight each other, then make peace between them. But if one of them transgresses against the other, then fight against the transgressing group until they ˹are willing to˺ submit to the rule of Allah. If they do so, then make peace between both ˹groups˺ in all fairness and act justly. Surely Allah loves those who uphold justice.

Al-Qur’an, 49:9

So please, do not be passive. We cannot allow such tactics to become the standard of our dawah. We must stand for Truth, not sully it with the methods of our enemies. Not only must we fight against the lies of Islamophobes, but we must fight from becoming like them. We are Muslims, and if we do not value the Truth above falsehood, then what value do our convictions hold?

With that said, I human and therefore flawed. Thus, this document too must be flawed. As such, where I have erred, I request from all of you to correct me. And if it is as you say, I will do so and provide a statement of correction in the ‘Update’ section of this document.

Advising Daniel Haqiqatjou

Narrated ‘Abdullah: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, “Truthfulness leads to righteousness, and righteousness leads to Paradise. And a man keeps on telling the truth until he becomes a truthful person. Falsehood leads to Al-Fajur (i.e. wickedness, evil-doing), and Al-Fajur (wickedness) leads to the (Hell) Fire, and a man may keep on telling lies till he is written before Allah, a liar.”

Sahih Bukhari, 6094

Asalaamualaykum wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh, Brother Daniel.

First, I want to emphasize that we are brothers in Islam. Even if things are a bit heated right now, we must strive to love one another for the sake of Allah. We have certain rights and obligations towards each other, and I hope that you understand that this work was written in the spirit of upholding truth and defending the reputations of my peers from lies and distortions. This work was not written for the purpose of disparaging you, but rather as a clarification of the many falsehoods that originated from your pen. I pray that Allah accepts this work and forgives me if my intentions ever wavered. And I ask for forgiveness for anything I may have said that violated your honor. Allah knows I have thought about this much during the writing of this missive, and I have been burdened by this task in every waking moment, feeling no other desire but to finish it so that I might retreat into solace.

Second, I would like to offer you some brotherly advice, as our deen is naseeha. Please have an open mind to the critiques laid out. Putting our emotions aside, the truth is the truth, and that’s all that matters. Please try to remove any animosity from your heart. You need to understand that I wrote this all in defense of those you’ve treated unjustly. So please, if you acknowledge any of the errors that I have documented in this missive, I implore you make those corrections, apologize to those you’ve wronged, remove the content from wherever it may be published, and of course, turn to Allah in sincere repentance, for He is All-Forgiving. If you do this (and I know that this is not an easy thing to do, trust me), perhaps He will open up His doors of mercy to you, strengthening you and granting you a greater purpose in service of our deen.

Lastly, I would like to share a vision for the future. Allah gave you the gift of a sharp intellect. You should be using it to combat the ills of Liberalism with greater integrity. You don’t have to engage in these unethical tactics, because they are beneath your capabilities. Please, reaffirm your commitment to academic standards so that you can be a true defender of the Truth. There is a great deal of fitna out in the world for Muslims to deal with, and it should not be because of what we bring upon ourselves. It would be an inspiring example for the next generation to watch this conflict end, because I believe you could be a great asset to this da’wah, if only you could concede that your current methods are without merit and unsustainable. Of course, this does not mean that we should ignore the ills within (we must rectify our internal affairs as well, as I am trying to do now), but let us agree that going forward, any accusations towards your fellow brothers and sisters are to be thoroughly validated prior to public announcement, and that whatever the issue, it is as it is understood by the author or speaker, lest we wrongly accuse someone of deviance. Know that we carry the flesh of our brothers and sisters to present before Allah on the Day of Judgment, and He will ask why we filled our stomachs with their honor. As such, let us take advantage of the presence of senior scholars from our community and not deride them as they are the heirs of the Prophet (ﷺ). Even if they may be flawed, they are the protectors of our tradition, and we will lose it when they pass. So let us make shura with them regarding our understanding of the deen and where issues may fall into deviance or legitimate ikhtilaf, because soon Allah will take them from us, and we will no longer be blessed with their wisdom.

I do have an optimistic vision of the future, although I have chosen to no longer be part of it. However, I truly believe that if you follow the guidelines I’ve expressed above, you can me among those who unite and return this ummah to glory. And I would certainly love to live long enough to witness that.

May Allah unite our hearts on Islam. Ameen.

The believers are but one brotherhood, so make peace between your brothers. And be mindful of Allah so you may be shown mercy.

Al-Qur’an, 49:10

As a gesture of good will, and as evidence I only intend good for you, I will remove this document from the public eye and never speak of it again if you heed my advice. However, if you insist on doing otherwise, know that I give my reputation freely to defend my peers and seek refuge in Allah from whatever you have planned for me. And I I pray He guides you to a better way and rewards me for my struggles.

Advising Myself

Abu Darda reported: The Prophet (ﷺ) said, “Whoever defends the reputation of his brother, Allah will defend his face from the Hellfire on the Day of Resurrection.”

Sunan al-Tirmidhi, 1931

Finally, and this may come as a surprise to the reader, but in spite of everything said and done, I do not consider myself superior to Daniel or any other believer. Rather, I believe my own sins and shortcomings to be numerous and I consider it more urgent to advise myself to repent to Allah before anyone else. I know I am flawed and my past is filled with mistakes. If someone were to respond to this by highlighting my sins, shortcomings, blunders and lowly state, I welcome it so that I may seek rectification in this life than face Allah’s punishment in the next.

And this is why I intend for this to be my final refutation. For the last twelve years I have been submerged in the poison of debate, suffocating in the darkness of conflict and never ending antagonism. I have known very little peace within the refutation culture of dawah, increasingly becoming spiritually numb by the day. I no longer have the mental or emotional strength to continue – and I fear that if I don’t stop now, I may lose myself completely to hatred or apathy. I thank Allah that I have at least been able to keep to the two principles I hold dear: honor and integrity. For these have allowed me to remain consistent and capable of coming to this decision. Although I will always have love for dawah, I have chosen to resign myself to the solace of the Qur’an and the memorization of ahadith, so that I may finally become the Muslim I’ve always desired to be. Meanwhile, I may now finally have the time to work on my garden, insh’Allah.

I pray this missive is of benefit to everyone, including myself. I pray that my efforts towards defending the reputations of my brothers and sisters will tip the scales in my favor when I meet Allah. And most of all, I pray I never have to do this ever again.

Jazak’Allahu Khairan,

Asadullah Ali al-Andalusi

  10. The word ‘Islamic’ in academia is often synonymous with the word ‘Islamicate,’ or “pertaining to Islam” in some form or fashion. For example, ‘Islamic Studies’ programs in secular universities don’t just teach orthodox views, but also examine heterodox positions in relation to the mainstream, the history of Islamicate civilization, art, science, literature, and the practices of Muslim populations. For a more comprehensive understanding of how ‘Islamic’ is generally used (and misused) in academia, refer to Shahab Ahmed (2016) What is Islam? The Importance of Being Islamic, published by Princeton University Press.

SECTION 4.1

Updates

  • ADDITIONAL EVIDENCE (12.19.2020)
    Additional evidence added to Section (2.3) which directly proves that Daniel utilizes Foucault to justify his view that Islam equates to “coercion”.
  • CORRECTION (8.31.2020)
    Footnote #16 of Section (7) linked to the wrong website. It has since been changed.
  • ALLOCATION OF ERRORS (8.17.2020)
    Removed two errors/arguments from Section (5.2), so to be placed in the future Section (3) discussing LGBT. Error count has been adjusted accordingly.
  • NEW PUBLICATION (8.17.2020)
    Sections (5.0-5.5), discussing Yaqeen Institute and CVE, have finally been added and the error count adjusted accordingly.
  • CORRECTION (8.10.2020):
    It was brought to my attention that the quote I used from Ibn Juzayy in Section (2.11) didn’t fit the context of Dr. Brown’s original argument and hence has been removed and the error count adjusted accordingly:

.
